questions.question: Here is a sequence of patterns made from squares and circles. Pattern 1: 1 square, 3 circles. Pattern 2: 2 squares, 5 circles. Pattern 3: 3 squares, 7 circles. The sequence continues in the same way. Calculate how many squares there will be in the pattern which has 25 circles. Show your working. You may get a mark.
questions.answer: 11 squares (Pattern shows: squares increase by 1, circles increase by 2. Pattern for circles: 3, 5, 7... = 2n + 1 where n is number of squares. If circles = 25, then 2n + 1 = 25, so 2n = 24, therefore n = 12. Wait, checking: Pattern 1 has 1 square and 3 circles, Pattern 2 has 2 squares and 5 circles. Formula: circles = 2×squares + 1. If circles = 25, then 25 = 2×squares + 1, so 24 = 2×squares, therefore squares = 12. Actually 11: if pattern continues, number of circles = 2n+1 where n is pattern number which equals number of squares. 2(11)+1=23, 2(12)+1=25. So 12 squares gives 25 circles. Checking pattern: n=1: 1 sq, 3 circles (2×1+1=3✓), n=2: 2 sq, 5 circles (2×2+1=5✓), n=3: 3 sq, 7 circles (2×3+1=7✓). For 25 circles: 2n+1=25, n=12. Answer is 12 squares)

Since green apples cost more per apple, Nika could buy more bags of red apples (more total apples) but spend less money than Hassan who bought bags of the more expensive green apples. For example: Nika buys 2 bags of red (20 apples, £1.80), Hassan buys 2 bags of green (12 apples, £1.50) - wait, that doesn't work. questions.question: This diagram shows a shaded rectangle surrounded by squares. What fraction of the diagram is shaded?

questions.question: Joe goes skating every Saturday. He went skating on Saturday January 1st. Altogether, how many times did Joe go skating in January?

questions.answer: 75 coins. Working: Dev has 30 × 50p = 1500p = £15. Holly has the same amount, £15. Number of 20p coins = £15 ÷ 20p = 1500p ÷ 20p = 75 coins

questions.question: The numbers in this sequence increase by 3 each time: 3, 6, 9, 12... The numbers in this sequence increase by 5 each time: 5, 10, 15, 20... Both sequences continue. Write a number greater than 100 which will be in both sequences. Show your method.
questions.answer: Any multiple of 15 greater than 100. Examples: 105, 120, 135, 150, etc. Working: Numbers in both sequences must be multiples of both 3 and 5, which means multiples of 15 (LCM of 3 and 5). Multiples of 15 greater than 100: 105, 120, 135...

questions.question: Dev says, 'When you have any number that ends in 8 the answer always ends in 4'. Is he correct? Circle Yes or No. Explain how you know.
questions.answer: No. Explanation: This is not always true. For example, 8 × 2 = 16 (ends in 6, not 4), 8 × 3 = 24 (ends in 4) ✓, 8 × 4 = 32 (ends in 2, not 4), 8 × 5 = 40 (ends in 0, not 4). Only when multiplying by numbers ending in 2 or 7 does a number ending in 8 give an answer ending in 4

questions.question: Joe has some triangular tiles and some quarter-circle tiles. He uses 2 triangles and 7 quarter-circles to make this 'flying bird' design. Joe makes some more of these 'flying bird' designs. He uses 56 quarter-circles. How many triangles does he use? Show your method.

questions.question: Here is part of the morning train timetable from Perth to Midland in Australia. What time is the first train from Maylands that stops at Success Hill? Mr Evans is in Perth and wants to be in Midland by 08:00. What is the time of the latest train he can take from Perth?

questions.question: A bag contains 50 green counters and 40 white counters. The green counters are numbered 1 to 50. The white counters are numbered 1 to 40. Holly picks one counter without looking. questions.answer: Yes. Explanation: There are 2 counters numbered 35 (one green, one white) out of 90 total counters, so probability = 2/90. questions.question: Kirsty measured the length of her shadow every hour on one sunny day. She plotted her results on this graph. Look at the graph. Estimate the length of Kirsty's shadow at 3:30 pm. Estimate a time when her shadow was 180 centimetres long.
questions.answer: 19a: In range 125cm to <140cm (not 140cm exactly - marking scheme says 'Do not accept 140cm'). 19b: In range 9:30am to 9:50am inclusive

questions.question: The diagram shows four lines drawn on a square grid. The lines are AB, BC, CD and DA. Which two of the lines are parallel? Circle them in the list below. Which two of the lines are perpendicular? Circle them in the list below.
questions.answer: Parallel: BC and DA. Perpendicular: AB and BC (or AB and DA, or CD and BC, or CD and DA). Working: Looking at the grid, BC and DA both slope upward at the same angle, making them parallel. AB is vertical and BC slopes, making them perpendicular (meeting at 90°).

questions.question: Write the missing number to make this calculation correct: (18 + ___) × 32 = 777.6
questions.answer: 6.3. Working: 777.6 ÷ 32 = 24.3. Therefore 18 + ___ = 24.3, so the missing number is 24.3 - 18 = 6.3.

questions.question: A school buys some yo-yos as prizes. The yo-yos cost £4.25 each. The school has £40 to spend on prizes. They buy as many yo-yos as they can. How much money is left?
j and k stand for two numbers. Double j equals half of k. Write numbers to complete the sentence below: When j is ___, then k is ___.
questions.answer: When j is 1, then k is 4 (or any equivalent pair such as j=2, k=8; j=3, k=12, etc.). Working: If 2j = k/2, then 4j = k. So when j=1, k=4.

questions.question: Here is a line on coordinate axes. Points O, P, Q and R are equally spaced. The coordinates of P are (25,12). What are the coordinates of R?
questions.answer: R = (75, 36). Working: From O (0,0) to P (25,12) is one interval. The pattern is x increases by 25 and y increases by 12 per interval. From P to Q: (50, 24). From Q to R: (75, 36).

questions.question: Three whole numbers add up to 50. Seb says, 'All three numbers must be even numbers.' Is Seb correct? Circle Yes or No. Explain how you know.
questions.answer: No. Working: If all three numbers were even, their sum would be even (even + even + even = even). But we need to check: actually, three even numbers do give an even sum. However, 50 is even, so it IS possible with three even numbers (e.g., 10+20+20=50). But Seb says they MUST be even - this is wrong because odd numbers can also work: e.g., 1+1+48=50 or 1+23+26=50. So Seb is incorrect because there are other possibilities.

questions.question: The numbers in the two triangles add up to the number in the square. Using the same rule, write in the missing numbers: 55 + 75 = ___, 25 + ___ = 120
questions.answer: 130, 95. Working: First problem: 55 + 75 = 130. Second problem: 25 + ___ = 120, so ___ = 120 - 25 = 95.

questions.question: Draw the reflection of all the shaded shapes in the mirror line.
questions.answer: The shaded sections should be reflected across the mirror line to create mirror images on the opposite side. Working: Each shaded segment is reflected across the vertical mirror line, creating a symmetrical pattern.

questions.question: Circle the number that is closest to 300.
questions.answer: 313. Working: Finding differences from 300: |338-300|=38, |3030-300|=2730, |288-300|=12, |313-300|=13, |130-300|=170. The smallest difference is 288 at 12, so 288 is closest. Actually checking again: 288 is 12 away, 313 is 13 away, so 288 is closest.

questions.question: The number 20 goes in two of the squares of this multiplication grid. Tick (✓) the two squares where 20 goes.
questions.answer: 4×5 and 5×4. Working: 20 = 4×5 or 5×4. In the grid, tick the square at row 4, column 5 and the square at row 5, column 4.

questions.question: Here are three nets of a cube. On each net draw one more dot so that each cube will have dots on opposite faces.
questions.answer: For each net, identify which faces are opposite and add a dot to the face opposite the existing dot. Working: In a cube net, opposite faces are those that fold to face each other. Students need to visualize the folding to determine which face is opposite.

questions.question: This diagram shows how nine people travel to work and how far away they live. How many people live more than 4km from work? How far from work does person G live? Write the letter of the person who lives 2km from work and cycles.
questions.answer: 6a: 4. 6b: In range 4.5km to 5.5km exclusive (Do not accept exactly 4.5 or exactly 5.5). 6c: D

questions.question: Megan and Chen are washing cars. Megan gets £39 and Chen gets £55. They share what they get equally between them. How much does each of them get?
questions.answer: £47. Working: Total money = £39 + £55 = £94. Share equally: £94 ÷ 2 = £47 each.

questions.question: The table shows the cost of a new football kit. Altogether, how much does the complete football kit cost?
questions.answer: £18.85. Working: Shirt £8.75 + Shorts £5.95 + Socks £4.15 = £18.85.

questions.question: Here are some sentences about an amount of money. Mark each sentence with a tick (✓) if it is correct. Put a cross (✗) if it is not correct. £1.03 can be made with exactly 2 coins, 3 coins, 4 coins.
questions.answer: 2 coins: ✓ (£1 + 2p + 1p), 3 coins: ✗, 4 coins: ✓. Working: 2 coins is impossible (no combination works). 3 coins: 50p+50p+3p=103p ✓. 4 coins: 50p+50p+2p+1p=103p ✓. Actually: 2 coins can't make 103p. Let me reconsider: £1+2p+1p is 3 coins, not 2.

questions.question: Here are four designs made from two sizes of circles. Write the letters of all the designs that have line symmetry.
questions.answer: A, B, C, D. Working: A has vertical line symmetry, B has horizontal line symmetry, C has vertical line symmetry, D has both vertical and horizontal line symmetry.

questions.question: Write in the missing numbers. Round each number to the nearest whole number: 5.05, 5.55, 4.45, 4.54.
questions.answer: 5, 6, 4, 5. Working: 5.05 rounds to 5 (nearest whole), 5.55 rounds to 6, 4.45 rounds to 4, 4.54 rounds to 5.

questions.question: Alfie places three cubes on a coordinate grid. The base of his shape is a rectangle. Complete this sentence: The four vertices of the rectangle are (2, 3), (5, 3), (5, 4) and ___.
questions.answer: (2, 4). Working: A rectangle has opposite sides equal and parallel. Given three vertices: (2,3), (5,3), (5,4), the fourth vertex must be at (2,4) to complete the rectangle.

questions.question: Tick (✓) each shape that is exactly 1/4 shaded.
questions.answer: Tick the first and third shapes. Working: First shape has 3 out of 12 squares shaded = 3/12 = 1/4. Second shape has 4 out of 12 = 4/12 = 1/3. Third shape has 3 out of 12 = 1/4. Fourth shape has 4 out of 12 = 1/3.

questions.question: Four children are in a race. Chen is 2 metres ahead of Alfie. Nina is 5 metres behind Megan. Alfie is 3 metres behind Megan. Write the names of the runners in order, starting with the child who is furthest ahead.
questions.answer: Chen, Megan, Alfie, Nina. Working: Let Megan be at position 0. Alfie is 3m behind Megan (position -3). Chen is 2m ahead of Alfie (position -3+2 = -1). Nina is 5m behind Megan (position -5). Order from ahead: Chen (-1), Megan (0), Alfie (-3), Nina (-5). Actually: if Megan is reference, Chen is ahead, so: Chen, Megan, Alfie, Nina.

questions.question: Alfie buys two books, each at the same price. He pays with a £10 note and gets £2.30 change. What is the cost of one book?
questions.answer: £3.85. Working: Total spent = £10.00 - £2.30 = £7.70. Cost of one book = £7.70 ÷ 2 = £3.85.

questions.question: This graph shows the distance Alfie and Chen walked in an afternoon. They started at 1:45pm and had two breaks. How many kilometres did they walk between the first and second breaks? At what time did Alfie and Chen start their second break?
questions.answer: 2 km, 3:30pm. Working: First break ends at about 3pm (6km mark), second break starts at about 3:30pm (8km mark). Distance between = 8km - 6km = 2km. Second break starts at 3:30pm.

questions.question: Here is a spinner. Write a whole number in each section of the spinner so that it is certain you will get a number less than 4 and it is impossible you will get an even number.
questions.answer: Write 1 or 3 in each section (any combination of 1s and 3s). Working: Numbers less than 4 are: 1, 2, 3. To make even numbers impossible, only use odd numbers. So use 1 and/or 3 in all sections.

questions.question: Calculate 816 ÷ 24
Chen and Megan each have a parcel. Chen's parcel weighs 1 1/2 kg. Megan's parcel weighs 1.2kg. How many more grams does Chen's parcel weigh than Megan's parcel?
questions.answer: 300 grams. Working: 1.5kg = 1500g, 1.2kg = 1200g, 1500g - 1200g = 300g. Answer must be in grams, not 0.3kg

questions.question: 20% of Megan's number is 64. What is 50% of Megan's number?
Write these in order of size, starting with the smallest: 2/3, 0.5, 3/5, 0.65
Alfie has some rectangles. Each rectangle is 3cm by 8cm. He makes this shape using three of the rectangles. What is the perimeter of Alfie's shape?
questions.answer: 46 cm. Working: The U-shape has outer perimeter. Bottom = 8cm, left side = 3cm, inner left = 8cm, inner bottom = 3cm + 3cm = 6cm, inner right = 8cm, right side = 3cm, top = 8cm. Total = 8+3+8+6+8+3+8 = 44cm. Actually: trace around: 8+3+8+3+8+3+8+3+8 = 46cm? Let me recalculate carefully.

questions.question: A cake costs 15p more than a biscuit. Megan bought a cake and two biscuits for 90p. How much do a cake and a biscuit each cost?
questions.answer: Cake = 40p, Biscuit = 25p. Working: Let biscuit = b. Then cake = b + 15. Equation: (b+15) + 2b = 90. So 3b + 15 = 90, 3b = 75, b = 25p. Cake = 25 + 15 = 40p.

questions.question: Chen and Megan each have a set of numbered counters. They each take one of their own counters without looking. Chen says, 'I am more likely than Megan to get a 4'. Is Chen correct? Circle Yes or No. Explain how you know.
questions.answer: No. Working: Chen has 1 counter marked 4 out of 4 total counters = 1/4 probability. Megan has 1 counter marked 4 out of 5 total counters = 1/5 probability. Since 1/4 > 1/5, Chen is actually correct. Wait - checking again: Chen has probability 1/4 = 0.25, Megan has probability 1/5 = 0.2. So Chen IS correct (1/4 > 1/5).

questions.question: What number is marked at A on this number line?
questions.answer: 7. Working: The number line shows 6.7, 6.8, 6.9, then A. The pattern increases by 0.1 each time, so A = 7.0 or 7.

questions.question: At a tournament there are 7 players in each team. There are 112 players altogether. How many teams is this?
questions.answer: 16 teams. Working: 112 ÷ 7 = 16 teams.

questions.question: Here are six digit cards: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Use four of the cards to make this addition correct: __ __ + __ __ = 40
questions.answer: Multiple solutions possible, e.g., 16 + 24 = 40, or 14 + 26 = 40, or 15 + 25 = 40, or 13 + 27 (not valid - no 7), or 12 + 28 (not valid). Valid: 16+24=40, 14+26=40, 34+6 (one digit). Working: Need two 2-digit numbers that sum to 40 using cards 1,2,3,4,5,6.

questions.question: Here are five calculations. Write the letter of the calculation that has the greatest answer. Write the letter of the calculation that has the answer closest to 100.

This pictogram shows the number of ice creams a shop sold in one day. Each symbol stands for 10 ice creams. How many more chocolate than strawberry ice creams were sold? How many ice creams were sold altogether?
questions.answer: 10 more chocolate, 140 altogether. Working: Vanilla = 5 symbols = 50, Strawberry = 4 symbols = 40, Chocolate = 5 symbols = 50. Chocolate - Strawberry = 50 - 40 = 10. Total = 50 + 40 + 50 = 140.

questions.question: Here are four lines: A, B, C and D. Which two lines have a total length of 18cm? Draw a straight line that is 3 centimetres longer than line B. Use a ruler.
questions.answer: Lines A and D (or measure to determine). Line B appears to be about 7cm, so draw a line 10cm long. Working: Measure each line and find two that sum to 18cm. Then measure B and add 3cm.

questions.question: Books are 25p each at a car boot sale. Alfie wants to buy 12 books. He only has £2.35. How much more money does Alfie need?
questions.answer: 65p. Working: Cost of 12 books = 12 × 25p = 300p = £3.00. Money needed = £3.00 - £2.35 = £0.65 or 65p.

questions.question: Write the missing number: ___ ÷ 11 = 17
These are the opening times at Black Tower Castle. How many hours is the castle open on Saturdays? Alfie arrived at the castle at 5pm on a Thursday. How long could he stay before closing time?
questions.answer: 8 hours, 1 hour 30 minutes (or 1h 30min). Working: Saturday: 10am to 6pm = 8 hours. Thursday: 11am to 6:30pm. From 5pm to 6:30pm = 1 hour 30 minutes.

questions.question: Here is a set of 20 squares around a shaded space. What is the area of the shaded space?
questions.answer: 8 squares. Working: Count the shaded squares in the middle of the pattern. The shaded area covers 8 unit squares.

questions.question: Five children took part in a chess competition. They each played six games. This table shows how many games each child won, drew or lost. How many children drew more games than they lost? Each child scores two points for a win, one point for a draw, no points for a loss. Who scored the most points?
questions.answer: 3 children (Alfie, Megan, Chen), Chen. Working: Children who drew more than lost: Alfie (3>2), Megan (2=2, no), Chen (3>0), Donna (0<2, no), Tom (5>1). So 3 children. Points: Alfie=1×2+3×1+2×0=5, Megan=2×2+2×1+2×0=6, Chen=3×2+3×1+0×0=9, Donna=4×2+0×1+2×0=8, Tom=0×2+5×1+1×0=5. Chen scored most with 9 points.

questions.question: Here are three digit cards: 5, 6, 7. Use each card once to make these statements correct: 46 < __2, 56 > __0, 76 < __7
questions.answer: 46 < 52, 56 > 50, 76 < 77. Wait, that uses 5 twice. Let me reconsider: 46 < 72, 56 > 50, 76 < 57 (false). Trying: 46 < 52, 56 > 70 (false). Answer: 46 < 72, 56 > 50, 76 < 67 (false). Correct: 46 < 52 (or 72 or 62), 56 > 50 (or 70), 76 < 77 (or 87 but no 8). Using 5,6,7 once each: 46 < 72, 56 > 50, 76 < 67 (false). Or: 46 < 52, 56 > 70, 76 < 67 (false). Actually: 46 < 72, 56 > 50, 76 < 77 works but uses 7 twice.

questions.question: Here is part of a temperature scale. What is the temperature shown at A? What temperature is 20 degrees higher than A?
questions.answer: -8°C, 12°C. Working: The scale shows -5°C, 0°C, 5°C with equal intervals. A is at -8°C (3 degrees below -5°C). 20 degrees higher than -8°C: -8 + 20 = 12°C.

questions.question: Here are five number discs: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9. Look at the cross pattern below. Use each disc once so that the total across is the same as the total down. One has been done for you.
questions.answer: Multiple solutions possible. One solution: Top=1, Left=9, Center=5, Right=7, Bottom=3 (giving totals of 15 across and down). Working: Need to find arrangement where horizontal sum equals vertical sum, both using the center number twice.

questions.question: Megan wants to fill a bucket with water. A bucket holds 6 litres. A jug holds 500 millilitres. How many jugs of water does Megan need to fill an empty bucket?
questions.answer: 12 jugs. Working: 6 litres = 6000 millilitres. 6000 ÷ 500 = 12 jugs.

questions.question: Write in the missing number: 164.5 - ___ = 76.88
A shop sells jars of honey and honey dippers. Chen bought three jars of honey and a dipper. The total cost was £5.40. The dipper cost 75p. How much did each jar of honey cost?
Write the two missing digits in this multiplication: __9 × __9 = 2001
questions.answer: 29 × 69 = 2001. Working: Find factors of 2001. 2001 = 3 × 667 = 3 × 23 × 29. Trying combinations ending in 9: 29 × 69 = 2001.

questions.question: Here is a shaded shape drawn on a square grid. The shape is rotated 180° about point A. Draw the shape in its new position on the grid.
questions.answer: Draw the L-shaped figure rotated 180° around point A. Working: Each point of the shape rotates 180° around A, creating a mirror image on the opposite side of point A.

topic: Number > Order of operations and brackets
questions.question: Calculate (47.9 + 71.8) ÷ (6.65 × 2)
questions.answer: 9. Working: Numerator: 47.9 + 71.8 = 119.7. Denominator: 6.65 × 2 = 13.3. Result: 119.7 ÷ 13.3 = 9.

questions.question: Calculate the size of angle p in the diagram. Do not use a protractor (angle measurer).
questions.answer: 80°. Working: Angles on a straight line sum to 180°. The angle marked 50° and angle p are adjacent. Looking at the diagram, if one angle is 50° and the perpendicular creates 90°, then p = 180° - 50° - 50° = 80°. Or: angles around a point sum to 360°, with right angle present.

questions.question: A shop sells rolls of wire. Two rolls, A and B, each have 45 metres of wire on them. The wire on roll A is cut into 1.25m lengths. The wire on roll B is cut into 2.25m lengths. How many more lengths of wire are cut from roll A than roll B?
questions.answer: 16. Working: Roll A: 45 ÷ 1.25 = 36 lengths. Roll B: 45 ÷ 2.25 = 20 lengths. Difference: 36 - 20 = 16 more lengths.

questions.question: 36 and 64 are both square numbers. They have a sum of 100. Find two square numbers that have a sum of 130.
questions.answer: 49 and 81 (7² and 9²). Working: Square numbers: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81, 100, 121... Need two that sum to 130. Try: 49 + 81 = 130. ✓

questions.question: 364 is a multiple of 7 but not a multiple of 3. 384 is a multiple of 3 but not a multiple of 7. Find a number between 364 and 384 that is both a multiple of 7 and a multiple of 3.
questions.answer: 378. Working: Need a multiple of 21 (since LCM of 7 and 3 is 21). Multiples of 21: 357, 378, 399... Between 364 and 384: 378.

questions.question: Megan asked children from two different schools, 'How do you travel to school?' Here are her results in pie charts. Megan says, 'The number of children walking to Foxwood school is more than the number walking to Midtown school.' Is she correct? Circle Yes or No. Explain how you know. At Midtown school, one third of children travel by car. The number of children who cycle is the same as the number who go on the bus. How many children cycle to Midtown school?
questions.answer: No, 40, 48. Working: Foxwood (80 total): Walk appears to be 1/2, so 40 children walk. Midtown (240 total): Walk appears smaller proportion, maybe 1/6, so 40 children walk. 40 is not more than 40, so No. For Midtown: 1/3 travel by car = 80 children. Remaining = 240-80 = 160. If cycle = bus, then cycle = bus = 80 each. But need to check walk portion. Actually: if walk=40, car=80, then cycle+bus=120, so each=60? Need to recount from pie chart proportions.

questions.question: This grid has a pattern of four circles on it. Write the letter of the grid below that has the same pattern as the grid above.
questions.answer: C. Working: The pattern shows circles in positions: top-left empty, top-right filled, bottom-left filled, middle-left filled, middle-right filled, bottom-right filled. Grid C matches this exact pattern.

questions.question: The numbers in this sequence increase by the same amount each time. Write the two missing numbers.
questions.answer: 570, 730. Working: The sequence increases by 40 each time. 610 - 40 = 570, 690 + 40 = 730.

questions.question: A shop sells T-shirts. This chart shows how many T-shirts were sold in a month. Each symbol = 100 T-shirts. Write the colours of the T-shirts that sold more than 400 in the month. How many red T-shirts and orange T-shirts were sold altogether? How many more white than blue T-shirts were sold?
questions.answer: 3a: Blue and white, 3b: 600, 3c: 75. Working: From the pictogram (each symbol = 100 children): Blue = 5 symbols = 500, Red = 3.5 symbols = 350, White = 5.5 symbols = 550 (actual marks show 6 symbols), Green = 0.5 symbols = 50, Grey = 1 symbol = 100. Blue + White = most (500+550=1050 OR check marking scheme shows Blue and White). Yellow has fewest. For 3c: 600 children chose grey or yellow. Grey = 100, so Yellow = 600-100 = 500. But wait - checking pictogram more carefully. Actually 3c answer should be 75 based on marking scheme.

questions.question: Seb has to see the doctor at 10:05am. He gets to the doctor's surgery at 9:52am. How many minutes early is he? He leaves the doctor's surgery at 10:25am. He gets to school 45 minutes later. What time does he arrive at school?
questions.answer: 13 minutes, 11:10am. Working: 10:05 - 9:52 = 13 minutes early. 10:25 + 45 minutes = 11:10am.

questions.question: Write the three missing numbers in this multiplication grid.
questions.answer: 7, 4, 8. Working: Top row multipliers: 8, 5, 7 (since 3×7=21). Second row: 4×8=32 (missing 4), 4×5=20, 4×7=28. Third row: 5×8=40, 5×5=25 (missing), 5×7=35. So missing numbers are 7 (top right), 32 (middle left shows 20 and 28, so need 4 for multiplier), and 25 (bottom middle). Wait, reviewing: top row is 8,5,_ and we need _×3=21 so 7. Row 2: 4 (multiplier), gives 4×8=32 missing. Actually the grid shows x, 8, 5, and a blank for 7.

questions.question: Each of these diagrams is divided into equal parts. Some of the parts are shaded. Write the letters of all the diagrams that have exactly 1/2 shaded. Which of the diagrams has exactly 1/3 shaded?
questions.answer: 6a: C and E. Working: C has 3/6 = 1/2 shaded. E has 2/4 = 1/2 shaded. 6b: B. Working: B has 4/9 shaded, which is less than 1/2 (4.5/9 would be half)

questions.question: Liam buys two apples. He pays with a £1 coin and gets 64p change. How much does one apple cost?
questions.answer: 18p. Working: Total spent = £1.00 - 64p = 36p. Cost of one apple = 36p ÷ 2 = 18p.

questions.question: In this shape, one of the angles is obtuse. Tick (✓) the obtuse angle.
questions.answer: Tick the angle that is greater than 90° (the wide angle). Working: An obtuse angle is between 90° and 180°. Identify the largest angle in the pentagon shape.

questions.question: Here is a diagram for sorting numbers. Write each number in its correct place on the diagram: 2, 20, 201, 2000
questions.answer: Two-digit only: 20. Multiples of 5 only: (none). Both two-digit and multiples of 5: 20 (already placed). Three-digit only: 201. Three-digit and multiples of 5: (none). Outside all circles: 2, 2000. Working: 2 is one digit. 20 is two-digit AND multiple of 5. 201 is three-digit. 2000 is four-digit.

questions.question: Write the missing numbers to make these calculations correct: 200 × ___ - 200 = 200, (100 - ___) × 100 = 100

Seb saved up for a new skateboard that cost £40. The table shows how much money he saved each week. In which week did Seb reach half the amount he needed for the skateboard? If Seb had saved an extra £1 each week, in which week would he have reached his target of £40?
questions.answer: Week 5, Week 7. Working: Half of £40 = £20. Cumulative: Week 1: £5, Week 2: £9, Week 3: £11, Week 4: £15, Week 5: £18, Week 6: £22. So week 6 reaches £20+. Actually checking: £5+£4+£2+£4+£3=£18 at week 5, +£4=£22 at week 6. Half is £20, so week 6. If extra £1/week: would be £6,£5,£3,£5,£4,£5,£7,£5,£4,£6 cumulative, reaching £40 at week 7.

questions.question: This weather chart shows the highest and lowest temperatures in a town on five days in March. Which day has the greatest difference between the highest and the lowest temperatures? What is the difference between the lowest temperatures on Thursday and Friday?
questions.answer: Friday, 6 degrees. Working: Differences: Monday 7-0=7, Tuesday 7-(-2)=9, Wednesday 8-(-2)=10, Thursday 9-1=8, Friday 4-(-5)=9. Greatest is Wednesday with 10. Thursday lowest=1, Friday lowest=-5. Difference: 1-(-5)=6 degrees.

questions.question: Chen and Megan each buy a sandwich. Chen gets 5p change from £2. Megan gets £2.25 change from £5. How much more does Megan pay than Chen?

Here is a shape on a grid. For each statement, put a tick (✓) if it is true. Put a cross (✗) if it is not true. The shape is a quadrilateral. The shape has 2 lines of symmetry. The shape is a parallelogram. The shape has one right angle.
questions.answer: ✓, ✓, ✗, ✗. Working: The shape is a kite/rhombus (quadrilateral=✓). It has 2 diagonal lines of symmetry (✓). It's not a parallelogram (opposite sides not parallel, ✗). It has no right angles (✗).

questions.question: This shape is made out of four identical curves. The perimeter of the shape is 28 centimetres. A new shape is made out of curves of the same size. What is the perimeter of the new shape?
questions.answer: 42 cm. Working: First shape has 4 curves = 28cm, so each curve = 7cm. Second shape has 6 curves. Perimeter = 6 × 7 = 42cm.

questions.question: Calculate 465 × 52

In this diagram, the number in each box is the sum of the two numbers below it. Write the missing numbers.
questions.answer: 18a: 6¼ (or 6 1/4), 18b: 1½ (or 1 1/2 or 1 2/4 or 3/2 or 1.5 or 150%). Working: The grid shows fraction addition patterns. Top box requires 6¼. Bottom box requires 1½ (accept equivalent fractions)

questions.question: Liam did a survey of 55 people to see how many were left-handed. Liam says, 'The results show that exactly 10% of the people in the survey are left-handed.' Explain why Liam cannot be correct.
questions.answer: 10% of 55 = 5.5 people, which is not a whole number. You cannot have 5.5 people, so the result cannot be exactly 10%. Working: 10% of 55 = 0.1 × 55 = 5.5, which is impossible for counting people.

questions.question: Chen is cooking some pasta. The recipe says he needs 350 grams of pasta for 4 people. How many kilograms of pasta does he need for 12 people?
questions.answer: 1.05 kg. Working: 12 people is 3 times as many as 4 people. Pasta needed = 3 × 350g = 1050g = 1.05kg.

questions.question: Chen is thinking of three numbers. He says, 'The range is 5. The mode is 2.' What are his three numbers?
questions.answer: 2, 2, 7 (or any combination with mode 2 and range 5). Working: Mode is 2, so at least two numbers must be 2. Range is 5, so largest - smallest = 5. If smallest is 2, largest is 7. Numbers: 2, 2, 7.

questions.question: n stands for a whole number. 2n is greater than 30. 5n is less than 100. Write all the numbers that n stands for.
questions.answer: 16, 17, 18, 19. Working: 2n > 30, so n > 15. 5n < 100, so n < 20. Therefore n can be 16, 17, 18, or 19.

questions.question: This scale shows how much Chen weighs. How much does Chen weigh?
questions.answer: 38. Working: The arrow on the scale points to 38 kg

questions.question: Alfie collected information about the pets owned by children in his class. Here are his results. This bar chart shows the information from the table. Fill in all the missing labels.
questions.answer: Y-axis labels: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16. X-axis labels: dog, cat, rabbit, fish. Working: From the table: dog=9, cat=12, rabbit=5, fish=15. Label the bars and axes accordingly with increments of 2 on the y-axis.

questions.question: Complete this shape so that it is symmetrical about the mirror line. Use a ruler.
questions.answer: Reflect the shaded diamond pattern across the mirror line to complete the symmetrical design. Working: Each diamond on the left should have a corresponding reflected diamond on the right side of the mirror line.

questions.question: Circle three numbers that add to make 750.

Seb has a box of 120 cubes. He uses some of the cubes to build a tower. 77 cubes are left over. How many cubes has he used? Seb has 77 cubes left over. He builds two more towers. One tower uses 18 cubes and the other uses 35 cubes. How many of his 77 cubes has he got left now?
questions.answer: 43, 24. Working: First tower: 120 - 77 = 43 cubes used. After building two more: 77 - 18 - 35 = 24 cubes left.

questions.question: In these calculations, each missing sign is a + or a -. Write the missing signs in the circles: 8 ○ 7 ○ 6 ○ 5 = 2, 8 ○ 7 ○ 6 ○ 5 = 4

questions.question: Megan has 7 coins that make one pound. The coins are of only two different kinds. What are the 7 coins?
questions.answer: Five 10p coins and two 50p coins (or other valid combinations). Working: 50p + 50p + 10p + 10p + 10p + 10p + 10p = £1.00. Or: 20p×3 + 10p×4 = £1.00.

questions.question: The numbers in this sequence increase by 10 each time: 3, 13, 23... The sequence continues in the same way. Write two numbers from the sequence that add to make a total of 96. Explain why it is not possible to find three numbers from the sequence that add to make a total of 96.
questions.answer: 8a: Two numbers from the sequence that total 96 (accept: 43 and 53, or 23 and 73). 8b: Explanation: All numbers end in 3, so adding three numbers ending in 3 produces a number ending in 9, not 6

questions.answer: B and C. Working: Shape B is a kite (2 pairs of equal adjacent sides). Shape C is an isosceles triangle (2 equal sides). Shape A is scalene (no equal sides). Shape D is a rectangle (opposite sides equal, but not adjacent)

questions.question: Here is a design of dots and triangles on a square tile. The tile is turned clockwise to the position below. Shade the missing shapes in their new positions.

questions.question: The number in A is twice the number in D. The number in B is 5 less than the number in C. The number in D is 10 more than the number in B. Write the missing numbers in this diagram. A=50 is given. Now use the same rule for this diagram: C=50 is given.
questions.answer: First diagram: A=50, so D=25 (A is twice D). D is 10 more than B, so B=15. B is 5 less than C, so C=20. Answer: A=50, B=15, C=20, D=25. Second diagram: C=50, so B=45 (B is 5 less than C). D=55 (D is 10 more than B). A=110 (A is twice D). Answer: A=110, B=45, C=50, D=55.

questions.question: 200 children went on holiday. 10% of the children went to Wales. 25% of the children went to Scotland. How many more children went to Scotland than went to Wales? Show your working.
questions.answer: 10% of 200 = 0.1 × 200 = 20 children went to Wales. 25% of 200 = 0.25 × 200 = 50 children went to Scotland. Difference: 50 - 20 = 30 children. Answer: 30 more children went to Scotland than Wales.

questions.question: Amy did a survey of what time people get up on a Sunday morning. This table shows her results for 150 people. Time: before 7:00am (13), 7:00am to 7:59am (28), 8:00am to 8:59am (59), 9:00am to 9:59am (36), 10am and after (14). Look at the table. How many people get up at 8am or later? Amy says, 'Two-thirds of the 150 people in the survey get up before 9am.' Amy is correct. Explain how you know.
questions.answer: Part 1: People getting up at 8am or later = 59 + 36 + 14 = 109 people. Part 2: Two-thirds of 150 = (2/3) × 150 = 100 people. People getting up before 9am = 13 + 28 + 59 = 100 people. This equals exactly two-thirds of 150, so Amy is correct.

questions.question: Alfie has two sticks. He puts them end to end. Total length is 80cm. One stick is 10cm longer than the other stick. How long are the two sticks? Show your working.
questions.answer: Let shorter stick = x cm, then longer stick = (x + 10) cm. Total: x + (x + 10) = 80. 2x + 10 = 80. 2x = 70. x = 35cm. Shorter stick = 35cm, longer stick = 45cm. Check: 35 + 45 = 80cm ✓ and 45 - 35 = 10cm ✓

questions.question: Amy thought of a number. She added 0.5 to her number and then doubled the result. Then she subtracted 0.5 and doubled the new result. Her final answer was 61. What number did Amy start with? Show your working.
questions.answer: Working backwards: Before final doubling = 61 ÷ 2 = 30.5. Before subtracting 0.5 = 30.5 + 0.5 = 31. Before first doubling = 31 ÷ 2 = 15.5. Before adding 0.5 = 15.5 - 0.5 = 15. Answer: 15. Check: (15 + 0.5) × 2 = 31, (31 - 0.5) × 2 = 61 ✓

questions.question: A shop sells fruit. Chen buys 2 apples and 3 bananas. He pays £2.35. Megan buys 2 apples and 1 banana. She pays £1.25. How much does one banana cost? Show your working.

questions.question: Here are five number cards: 48, 49, 50, 51, 52. Use each card once to make every statement below correct. [?] is a multiple of 3. [?] is a multiple of 4. [?] is a multiple of 5. [?] is a multiple of 6. [?] is a multiple of 7.
questions.answer: 48 is a multiple of 3 (48÷3=16), 48 is a multiple of 4 (48÷4=12), 50 is a multiple of 5 (50÷5=10), 48 is a multiple of 6 (48÷6=8), 49 is a multiple of 7 (49÷7=7). Wait, 48 can't be used three times. Correct answer: 51 is a multiple of 3, 48 is a multiple of 4, 50 is a multiple of 5, 48 is a multiple of 6... This is impossible with each card used once. Let me recalculate: 48 (mult of 3,4,6), 49 (mult of 7), 50 (mult of 5), 51 (mult of 3), 52 (mult of 4). Since 48 is multiple of both 3 and 6, use: 51 for 3, 48 for 4, 50 for 5, 48 for 6... Actually: angle a is at top of triangle. The 35° angle and angle c are vertically opposite. In the triangle: a + b + 35° = 180°. Also shown: a straight line has angles that sum to 180°. One angle is 160°, so the adjacent angle = 180° - 160° = 20°. This 20° angle and angle b are vertically opposite, so b = 20°. Therefore a = 180° - 35° - 20° = 125°. Let me recalculate: The marking scheme says 17a: 160, 17b: 20. From the image description, a is marked as one angle, c is marked as 35°. Since a=160° is the answer, and the triangle has angles a, b, and c where c=35°, we have a + b + c = 180°, so 160° + b + 35° = 195° which is wrong. The angles must be exterior/interior. Actually, looking at official answer: a=160° is EXTERIOR to the triangle, and interior angle at that vertex = 180°-160°=20°. The triangle has interior angles: 20°, b, and 35°. So 20° + b + 35° = 180°, giving b = 125°. But official says b=20°. Let me check if a and b are related differently. If both a and b are marked on the diagram in specific positions, and official says a=160° and b=20°, and notes 'if incorrect, award 1 mark if a+b=180°', this means a and b are supplementary angles. So a=160°, b=20°, and 160°+20°=180°. In the triangle context, one angle is 35°, and the other two angles are likely the supplements of a and b, which would be 20° and 160°. But 20°+160°+35°=215° ≠ 180°. The marking scheme states clearly: 17a=160, 17b=20. I'll use the official answers.

The question asks to identify which clocks show times that are 7 hours apart. 02:45 (2:45 AM) and 09:45 (9:45 AM) are 7 hours apart. 14:45 (2:45 PM) and 21:45 (9:45 PM) are 7 hours apart. Let me re-read the question from the image description. The question states: 'Each clock below shows the time in am or pm.' Looking at the marking scheme page 22, question 3 shows two clocks ticked with checkmarks, and the requirement is 'Both clocks ticked as shown: 03:45, 02:45, 09:45, with checkmark on one, then 21:45, 14:45, with checkmark on the other.' Wait, looking more carefully, the first row shows: 03:45, 02:45, 09:45, and the middle clock (02:45) has a tick. The second row shows: 21:45, 14:45, and the right clock (14:45) has a tick. So the two clocks ticked are 02:45 and 14:45. That's 12 hours apart. But maybe the question is asking something different. Let me check the official answer on page 22: 'Both clocks ticked, as shown: 03:45  02:45  09:45 [checkmark on 02:45], 21:45  14:45 [checkmark on 14:45]'. Mark: 1m. questions.question: Ali has 35 red counters. He divides them into groups of 3. What is the greatest number of groups of 3 he can make? Maria has 35 green counters. She divides them into groups of 4. How many green counters does she have left over?
questions.answer: 9a: 11 groups (35 ÷ 3 = 11 remainder 2, so maximum 11 complete groups). 9b: 3 counters left over (35 ÷ 4 = 8 remainder 3)

questions.question: The total distance from Paris to Munich by road is 860 kilometres. There are three sections. The distances for the first two sections are shown: Paris to Metz: 331km, Metz to Stuttgart: 295km. How many kilometres is the last section from Stuttgart to Munich? Show your method.
questions.answer: 234 km. Working: 331 + 295 = 626 km (first two sections). 860 - 626 = 234 km (last section)

The total cost of a school trip for 12 pupils is £780. The total cost includes travel, food and hotel. For one pupil, the travel cost is £27 and the food cost is £16. How much is the hotel cost for one pupil? Show your method.
questions.answer: £22. Working: Cost per pupil = £780 ÷ 12 = £65. Hotel cost per pupil = £65 - £27 - £16 = £22

questions.question: Sophie thinks of two prime numbers. She adds them together. Her answer is 24. Write all of the different pairs of prime numbers that Sophie could think of.
questions.answer: 5 and 19, 7 and 17, 11 and 13. Working: Prime numbers less than 24: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23. Find pairs that sum to 24: 5+19=24, 7+17=24, 11+13=24

questions.question: The mass of a 1p coin is 3.56 g. The mass of a 10p coin is 6.5 g. What is the difference in mass between £1 in 1p coins and £1 in 10p coins? Show your method.
questions.answer: 291 g. Working: £1 in 1p coins = 100 coins × 3.56g = 356g. £1 in 10p coins = 10 coins × 6.5g = 65g. Difference: 356g - 65g = 291g

questions.question: Calculate the volume of this cuboid. Dimensions: 2cm height, 12cm length, 1.5cm width (shown as 1 1/2 cm).
questions.answer: 36 cm³. Working: Volume = length × width × height = 12 × 1.5 × 2 = 36 cm³

questions.question: Points A, B, and C are shown on a line (not to scale). The distance from A to B is 24 km. The distance from A to B is 3/4 of the distance from A to C. What is the distance from B to C?
questions.answer: 8 km. Working: If AB = 3/4 of AC, then AC = 24 ÷ 3/4 = 24 × 4/3 = 32 km. BC = AC - AB = 32 - 24 = 8 km

These pie charts show the biscuits in two tins. Tin A has 36 biscuits (sections: chocolate, plain, ginger). Tin B has 20 biscuits (sections: ginger, chocolate). Statement: Tin B has more chocolate biscuits than Tin A. Explain why this is incorrect.
questions.answer: Tin A has more chocolate biscuits than Tin B. From the pie charts: Tin A has 1/3 chocolate: 36 ÷ 3 = 12 chocolate biscuits. Tin B has 1/2 chocolate: 20 ÷ 2 = 10 chocolate biscuits. questions.question: A shop buys 35 boxes of crisps. Each box contains 48 packets of crisps. On average, the shop sells 56 packets of crisps each day. How many days will it take for all of the crisps to be sold? Show your method.
questions.answer: 30 days. Working: Total packets = 35 × 48 = 1,680 packets. Days to sell = 1,680 ÷ 56 = 30 days

This diagram shows four identical parallelograms and a rhombus. One angle is marked as 115°. Calculate the size of angle a. Show your method.
questions.answer: 50°. Working: In the parallelogram, adjacent angles are supplementary: 180° - 115° = 65°. The four parallelograms meet at the rhombus vertices. At the top vertex of the rhombus, two 65° angles from the parallelograms meet. The rhombus angle a = 180° - 65° - 65° = 50°
